comment.narrative: Zero

1). NA 2). Number of dialogues/interaction workshops hosted on key constitutional issues 3). 6 Option Papers developed and shared with CA members and political leaders 4). Educate 8500 General public and local level stakeholders on key constitutional issues and 15000 public feedback to the CA on draft constitution 5). Two Knowledge product developed and distributed 7). 95 lawyers trained 8). 9 Interactions events on gender and social inclusion issues

1). NA 2). Gaps narrowed between the major political parties through 36 informed dialogues, interactions, meetings, and consultations on constitutional issue which contributed to promulgate the new constitution 3). 6 Option Papers developed and shared with CA members and political leaders 4). A total of 8842 general public/civil society members, media, and local leaders educated on key constitutional issues. Among them, 31 % was female. As a result, more than 15500 Public feedback provided to the CA in draft constitution. 5). Two Knowledge product developed and distributed on participatory constitution making process and its contemporary issues, Nepali version of Federal Life 7). 95 Young lawyers trained 8). 9 Interactions events organized on gender and social inclusion issues

1). Parliament Outreach Strategy in Nepal. A comprehensive need assessment is planned for 2016.
3) 22 Parliamentarians trained on evaluation skills and 22 women Parliamentarians trained on dealing with Media and communication skills 4) A mock youth parliament conducted for 100 youths and debated on Federalism and quota system 5) One knowledge Product on civic education material on new constitutional provisions 6) 1140 general public educated on constitutional provisions . 7). Two interaction events completed: To review the existing provisions from women and dalit perspective, identifying gaps and ways forward

description.narrative: Fostering Rural Livelihoods Recovery and Resilience of Earthquake Affected Communities in Nepal.
Support to Nepals transition through improved UN coherence
Transition Support Strategy through improved UN Coherence.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: Resident Coordinators Annual Reports UNCT Annual Workplans and UNCT Annual Report UNDAF Annual Report and M&E Framework

Enhance the capacity of the UN Country Team and Development Partners to programme and communicate on key issues and priorities for Nepal's transition phase by heavily capitalizing on field based insights. In the aftermath of the earthquakes on 25 April and 12 May assist with the coordination of the Humanitarian Community. An effective and better coordinated approach is applied to implement the UNDAF 2013-2017 though internalizing the Delivering as One principles and procedures.

The 2014 UNDAF Annual Report was developed and endorsed by the UNDAF Steering Committee. UNCT has strengthened coordination on technical support, programming and advocacy on Youth, SDGs, Reconstruction and Transition . The interagency UN M&E Group contributed to the collaborative approach to national capacity building on M&E and updated the UNDAF M&E framework. UN coordination for risk reduction and disaster preparedness has been strengthened through a reconfigured and well functioning HCT incorporating key humanitarian donors and I/NGOs. The UN advanced a victim centric approach to Transitional Justice through the strengthening of the conflict victims common platform on Transitional Justice- a joint initiative of UNRCO, OHCHR, UNDP. The UN provided technical support to advocacy in conflict related sexual Violence achieved (CRSV). The UN undertook joint coordination, advocacy and technical support on Non-discrimination and Social Inclusion issues. UN leadership with National Human Rights Commission on the Protection Cluster provided a forum for technical coordination with development partners and NGOs on human rights concerns and protection issues including for emergency response and post-earthquake work. The UN Country Team also provided support for the UPR process. In the aftermath of the earthquakes the RCHCO provided support to the RC/ HC in his capacity as humanitarian coordinator as well as supporting OCHA in their response work.

description.narrative: Safeguarding peace building gains in Nepal support for coordination, planning, monitoring and evaluation of UNPFN
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
Shared UNCT-donor-government understanding of UNPFN and the most appropriate contribution of the Fund and its projects to safeguarding peacebuilding gains.

comment.narrative: Project implementation and UNPFN Executive Committee decision-making facilitated for UNPFN functionality at administrative and strategic levels

Final independent project evaluations of 2012 Funding Round project completed and assessed as part of initiation of the overall UNPFN Evaluation, as part of overall development of a strategy for the closure of the UNPFN.

5/7 of UNPFN 2012 Funding Round projects completed at least a draft final project evaluation and the UNPFN Evaluation (2007-2015) contract was signed. UNPFN Executive Committee communications and decision-making facilitated after the earthquake to provide blanket three-month no cost extensions to projects affected by the disaster.

description.narrative: Following new agreement with DFID on 15/06/2015, the project is a merger of the NRRC (relocated from CDRMP to RCO) and the Common Feedback Project for the EQ
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

During 2016 momentum can be built to utilize the data and evidence that already exists on risk in Nepal and to conduct a national level dialogue at senior level within the Government of Nepal and the international community on resilience. This would lead to a longer term Government-led plan of action.

comment.narrative: Following the earthquake of 2015 work at project and progamme level continues under the NRRC 5 Flagship format. The inevitable focus on response and recovery from the earthquake has not permitted the necessary national level dialogue on resilience and DRR following Sendai. NRRC was to have reconsidered priorities at the end of 2015 with a view to resetting the agenda from 2016 onwards. It is expected that this will be possible only from the second quarter onwards of 2016 at the earliest.
Completion of risk assessment approach to further a 2016 national debate on risk and resilience in Nepal relating to Sendai, SDGs, and COP21

NRRC workplan prioritized development of public private partnership strategy and national risk assessment approach. Both were to contribute to a reconsideration of NRRC priorities for 2016-2020. Both processes were interrupted by the 2015 earthquake though the first phase of each had been completed.

1. Support MoHA, focal point systems and members of DM national platform to a) review the 10 years HFA progress 2. Support to enhance capacity of teachers/trainers of CTEVT 3. Trainings to engineers/professional engineers, orientation to local leaders, house owners, private sectos ) completed. 7. E-BPS support provided to KMC, LSMC. e-BPS by KMC formally launched. 8. The construction of gabion spurs and launching aprons have been carried out in Pasaha Khola Parsa.

title.narrative: Ecosystem Based Adaptation in Mountain Ecosystems

description.narrative: Ecosystem Based Adaptation in Mountain Ecosystems in Nepal
Priority adaptation actions implemented in selected districts to build communities resilience to climate change
# of ecosystem based adaptation measures identified and applied

comment.narrative: No ecosystem based adaptation measures exist

(1) EbA Option Implementation
(2) Carry out Economic valuation of EbA optins
(3) EbA integrated in plan and policies of Government of Nepal

(1) Following EbA optionsimplemented 1. Making water resources and facilities resilient and adaptive by Conservation of water sources, and Pond Rehabilitation 2. Forest and Biodiversity Conservation through plantation and forest mgt 3. Degraded land rehabilitation and managment 4. Climate resilient road design, construction and Managment.
(2) Cost benefit analysis of three EbA options completed.
(3) Ecosystem Based Adaptation approach was replicated in Shivapuri & Nagarjun National Park and integrated into Protection Forest Directives.

title.narrative: Community Based Flood and Glacial Lake Risk Redcution

description.narrative: Reduce human and material losses from Glacial Lake Outburst Flood (GLOF) events in Solukhumbu District and catastrophic flooding events in the Tarai and Churia Range of Nepal

title.narrative: Community Based Flood and Glacial Lake Risk Redcution

description.narrative: Output 7.3.2 Reduction of water level in Imja glacier lake and risk mitigation measures adopted in four most vulnerable Tarai districts
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

At least 100% of the population (men and women) who are directly vulnerable to GLOF impacts within the 27 high risk settlements GLOF Impact Zone are covered by a comprehensive community-based Early Warning System (CBEWS)

comment.narrative: More than 31,862 people live in the high risk settlements of Imja GLOF Impact Zone and are directly vulnerable to GLOF impacts. They have no EWS. Other forms of disaster preparedness are also limited.

GLOF preparedness at Imja Lake and Khumbu region through (i) installation of Community Based Early Warning Systems (CBEWS), (ii) logistic support to Evacuation Centers and (iii) formation of 12 Task Forces at vulnerable settlements implemented.
Flood preparedness implemented through installation of CBEWS in the Five river basins in Terai and through conduction of Flood Risk Management trainings.

Based on the recommendation received from Hazard Mapping and Safety and Evacuation Plan (H/SEP), evacuation centers have been strengthened; taskforces have been formed and operationalized and CBEWS equipment have been installed in 15 strategic locations manual gauges; hand operation sirens and hand mikes under component I. A set of different activities such as street dramas, mock drills, trainings, production and dissemination of Information, Education and Communication (IEC) materials, GLOF risk reduction preparedness issues in communities and further institutionalization of risk reduction knowledge and skills.
Major milestones have been achieved in the construction of structural measures for flood risk reduction i.e. 4.4 Km embankment with gabion revetment work and bioengineering, 4.5 km Flood Proofing Drainage System (FDPS) and 6 Elevated Tube Wells (ETWs) have been constructed along with 18 Community Based Early Warning System (CBEWS)/ Community Based Flood Early Warning System (CBFEWS) have been installed under component II. A significant achievement has been made in terms of institutionalization of Sediment Monitoring Protocols (SMP). As such, the SMP has been published and disseminated as a major knowledge product by project. Furthermore, a national level training for the officials from DHM, DWIPD, DSCWM and President Churia Madhesh Terai Conservation Development Board (PCMTCDB) on Flood Hazard and Sediment Modeling has been conducted to further institutionalize the methodologies and techniques of sediment monitoring as per SMP.

description.narrative: To reduce human and material losses from Glacier Lake Outburst Flooding (GLOF) in Solukhumbu District and catastrophic flooding events in the Tarai and Churia Range

Number of high risk settlements of the GLOF Impact Zone of Solukhumbu district downstream of Imja lake area covered by an Early Warning System (EWS) [refer to AMAT 1.2.1.2]
Number of institutions with increased capacity to minimize human and material losses from potential GLOF events in the High Mountains and climate-related flooding in the Tarai and Churia Range [refer to AMAT 2.2.1]

comment.narrative:
As per the updated Baseline developed by the project - Within 50 km downstream from the Imja Glacial Lake mainly covering 4 VDCs among which Khumjung, Namche, Chaurikharka lies in SNP Buffer Zone and adjoining Juving VDC which lies outside the buffer zone are identified as vulnerable VDCs. Altogether 40 settlements, having 3,278 households with 12,690 population, which lie in 4 VDCs were identified as vulnerable from Imja GLOF.
Primary beneficiaries: 4,360 population residing in permanent settlements with critical risk of GLOF.
Secondary Beneficiaries: 12,690 residing along 50 km downstream from Imja Lake in 40 permanent settlements. This includes the 4,360 primary beneficiaries as well.
Tertiary Beneficiaries: Annual floating population 74,992 (24,994 tourist + 49,998 porters) and VDC people residing along the trekking route and Imja Khola and Dudhkoshi River.
Total Beneficiaries: A total of 87,682 population including permanent residents and annual floating population in the area.
The initial estimation of total beneficiaries was only 31,862. However, the study conducted by project on GLOF Hazard Zonation and Safety Evacuation Plan explored that the total of 87,682 people will be benefited from the GLOF risk reduction activities in Khumbu region. Thus, project will be using the updated data instead of the numbers reported in project document.
Infrastructure: 5.5 km road, 94 km trail, 25 truss and suspension bridges, 0.5 river embankment, 0.5 irrigation canal, three schools, four office buildings, 137 hotels, 64 teashops, three temple, gumba and mosque, two hydropower dam, five water mills, seven transmission lines and one industry.
Total direct & indirect costs of potential GLOF damages including replacement of major infrastructure estimated as $8.98 billion.
Weak system for flood risk management (only construction work is done) in DWIDP.
There is only a district level Disaster Relief Committee though no GLOF risk management committee formed in Solukhumbu district.
DDRC is mostly involved in rescue and relief for post disaster work and their activity in the targeted districts is limited.
Limited trained staff in DHM to work in GLOF risk reduction.

By the end of the project, at least 100% of the population (men and women) who are directly vulnerable to GLOF impacts within the 27 high risk settlements GLOF Impact Zone are covered by a comprehensive Community-Based Early Warning System (CBEWS).
By the end of the project, targeted training/on the job training in gender sensitive flood risk management including disaster preparedness will have been provided to at least 32 technical staff from 2 key government departments, DHM (2 senior level) and DWIDP (30 district and regional level), 30 representatives from 5 DDRCs, 64 representatives from 1 GLOF Risk Management Committee and at least 2 university students.
DHM will have the necessary technologies, skills & systems to assess and effectively communicate GLOF risk levels and warnings.
DWIDP will have the necessary technologies, skills & systems to monitor sediment load in flood-prone river basins in the Tarai & Churia Range.
The Annual District Plans of at least 3 of the 5 target project districts incorporate budgeted flood risk preparedness activities.

Twelve Taskforces each containing three sub-groups of search and rescue, first aid and early warning have been formed during March 2015 in project area. All Taskforces have been equipped with necessary First Aid (FA), Light Search and Rescue (LSAR) and Community Based Early Warning System (CBEWS) equipment and trained total 152 members on use of equipment during GLOF and any climatic hazards on June 2015.
CBEWS have been installed in 15 identified locations along the 50 km stretch downstream from Imja during June 2015.
First round of training on "Flood Risk Management and Sediment Monitoring" was organized during 18-21 August 2014 at Lahan for district level officers. Another training was organized during 17-20, November 2014 for national level officials. As a follow-up of first round, training on Flood risk management and sediment monitoring is planned for third quarter 2015.
Sediment Monitoring Protocols for Churia Originating River Systems was developed and shared to DHM, DWIDP and DSCMW which aims toward internalizing the Protocols in their sediment database management system.

description.narrative: Risks of human and material losses from Glacial Lake Outburst Flooding (GLOF) events from Imja Lake reduced

Average depth of Imja lake
[refer to AMAT 1.2.1.2]
Percentage of high risk settlements of Imja GLOF Impact Zone residents (including women, children and elderly people) with a clear understand of how the EWS works and what to do in the event of a GLOF
[refer to AMAT 2.1.2.1 / 3.1.1.1]
Number of targeted institutions with increased capacity to minimize exposure to GLOF risks
[refer to AMAT 2.2.1.1 / 2.2.2.1 / 2.3.1.1/2 / 3.2.1.1]

comment.narrative:
Updated baseline data: Average water depth of Lake is 58.8 m and highest water depth was 149.8 m in October 2014
90% of the community have heard about GLOF about GLOF risk but are not prepared for it (Source: Regional GLOF Risk Reduction Project)
X number of female and Y number of male are aware of the potential risk of GLOF and benefits of EWS.
No local institution to address or understand the GLOF risk which is creating unnecessary havoc of outburst.
Limited access to information as well as Government level institution in the Khumbu region (Imja lake and surrounding) to address or disseminate GLOF risks.

Average depth of lake kept below danger level by ensuring average water depth during spring and summer months is at least 3 meters or more below the baseline level prior to the construction of the channel.
100% residents from Solukhumbu district of the high risk settlements of the GLOF Impact Zone (within 50 km of outlet) understand how the EWS works and know what to do during the event of a GLOF, including men and women and elder residents.
Number of representatives from Solukhubmu DDRC, Sagarmatha National Park, the Imja GLOF Risk Management Committee, and CBEWS Taskforces trained to manage and minimize GLOF risks.
No. & type of information materials disseminated to local and non-local people (i.e. tourists) by different agencies on GLOF risks, risk reduction measures and what to do in the event of a GLOF.
By the end of the project, DHM is operating a GLOF Risk Monitoring System and has a mechanism in place to communicate GLOF risk warnings to MoHA and NEOC.

Lake lowering design and other associated studies such as Electric Resistivity Tomography (ERT), Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) investigation and Bathymetric survey of the lake were completed on December 2014. Based on these studies, the design for lake lowering was completed in the first quarter 2015.
Invitation to Bid (ITB) to undertake the construction activities of lake lowering has been announced.
12 Taskforces consisting of early warning, FA and LSAR sub-groups have been formed along the stretch of 50 km downstream from the Imja lake under the umbrella of GMRCC during March 2015.
20 Local Resource Persons (LRPs) consisting of 13 male and 7 female members have been developed and trained on GLOF risk management Training of Trainer (ToT) in 2014.
CBEWS tools and equipment have been handed over to Taskforce and training to handle and equipment use was organized during June 2015.
Mobile Apps to disseminate information related to GLOF risk reduction has been developed during January 2015. Communication medium (IRIDUM system) is being extended by Government/Private in the project site after which this apps will be functional & operational.
Study on automatic Imja GLOF EWS with cost effective data transfer from equipment at Imja Lake to local community and DHM web portal was completed during December 2014.

description.narrative: Human and material losses from recurrent flooding events in 4 flood-prone districts of the Tarai and Churia Range reduced

Number of additional people provided with access to safe water supply and basic sanitation services
[refer to AMAT 1.2.3]
Number of people and value of their material assets covered by a CBEWS in the four target project districts
[refer to AMAT 2.2.2.1 / 3.1.1.1 / 3.2.1.1]
Number of targeted institutions with increased capacity to minimize exposure to flood risks in the Tarai & Churia Range
[refer to AMAT 2.2.1.1 / 3.2.1.1]

comment.narrative:
Existing tube wells in 8 VDCs get flooded during the flooding season hindering the access to safe drinking water for 59,062 population residing in the villages.
Water supply/drainage system in 8 VDCs gets flooded making it difficult for 59,062 population.
The initial estimation of the population for six VDCs which get flooded during the flooding season was 22,500. Likewise, the population estimation of four VDCs in which water supply/drainage get flooded in monsoon was 14,500. However, the detail study carried out by the project called Project related Baseline Socio-Economic data of Eight Project covering VDCs of Terai and Churia Region came up with the updated number i.e. 59,062 population from total eight VDCs will be beneficiaries of the project. Thus, project will be using the updated data instead of the numbers reported in project document.
There are no EWS in the 4 project target districts; 3 VDCs ((Mahisthan, Hattilet and Aurahi) communities in Mahottari district Janagha River) have been trained in CBEWS UNDP/CDRMP programme
The total population of the most flood-prone VDCs is 59,062.
Weak system for flood risk management. DWIDP currently focuses only on construction works.
Limited trained staffs in DWIDP on flood risk management.
DDRC is mostly involved in rescue and relief for post disaster work and their activity in the targeted districts is limited.

At least 70% population in 3 districts/6 VDCs have access to 24 elevated tube wells and/or a flood proofing drainage system.
100% of the population covered by CBEWS in all target flood prone river basins
By the end of the project, at least 8 gender sensitive Village Disaster Management Plans prepared by the Village Disaster Risk Management Committees in the Terai & Churia Range.
By the end of the project, at least two vulnerable VDCs of four districts will have CBEWSs and which are being effectively maintained by local communities (including women) under the leadership of the Village Management Committees.

35 Elevated Tube Wells were constructed in the four districts/8 target VDCs. Hence this ensures about 75% population have access to safe drinking water during flood.
About 4.5 km long Flood Proofing Drainage System has been constructed by the end of June 2015.
Total of eight Village Disaster Risk Management Committees (VDRMCs) and 35 Community Disaster Management Committees (CDMCs) have been formed and operationalized during July 2014. A total of 399 members are affiliated in 35 CDMCs including 200 female and 199 male.
Altogether, 28 FA Taskforces and 27 LSAR Taskforces have been formed under CDMCs and operationalized during July 2014. Likewise, 23 CBEWS Taskforces have been formed during March 2015.
Taskforces were equipped with relevant equipment during March 2015.
Training on LSAR and FA to members of Taskforces have been conducted during June 2015. A total of 213 members were trained including 87 female.
A total of 44 District and national level officials from DWIDP and DSCWM have been trained on Flood Risk Management & Sediment Monitoring during August and November 2014 respectively.
Training on Mainstreaming Flood Risk Management in Development Planning Process was also conducted to VDC level officials during August 2014.

title.narrative: Armed Violence Reduction & Strengthening Community Secur

description.narrative: Armed Violence Reduction & Strengthening Community Security in Nepal

title.narrative: AVRSC-General Revision 1 dtd 3 March2014 with AWP
Armed Violence Reduction & Strengthening Community Secur
Armed Violence Reduction & Strengthening Community Secur
Armed Violence Reduction & Strengthening Community Secur
Armed Violence Reduction & Strengthening Community Secur

description.narrative: Armed Violence Reduction & Strengthening Community Security in Nepal

activity-description.narrative: Support Government of Nepal to make measurable reduction in the risk and incidence of Armed Violence in the nine Southern Districts of Nepal namely Morang, Saptari, Bara, Parsa, Dhanusha, Banke, Bardiya, Kailali and Kanchanpur.

description.narrative: 1.Functional NCOC Department established and staffs trained in NP Academy 2.National Strategy and Action plan on SALW developed in line with Government work plan on small arms control and ISACS. 3.MoHA-led coordination structure on AVR strengthened through Secretariat support; 4.Conflict and gender Sensitive community security plans developed and implemented in the project districts by the end of project. 5.# of VDC/district reached through AVRSCS awareness raising activities (# of male and female reached)

comment.narrative: 1. Existence of multiple databases with the Nepal Police non-conversant to each other. Consolidated analysis of crime and violence data impossible. 2. National strategy and action plan on SALW not aligned with the International Small Arms Control Standards (ISACS). 3. MoHA led coordination Secretariat on AVR inexistent 4. Trust deficit among the security providers and community members. 5. Limited knowledge on laws and policies related to crime and violence prevention, youth violence, gender based violence and small arms and light weapons.

1. Completion of the System Requirement Analysis and initiation of the reengineering of the Crime and Criminal Information System (CCIS), Daily Incident Reporting System (DIRS) and Personnel Management Information System (PMIS). Development of NCOC software initiated. 2. Develop an action plan for stockpile management based on ISACS recommendations. 3. Support to bilateral security coordination between Nepal and India primarily at the Nepal India border at the project districts. 4.Implementation initiated for 6 VDC cluster action plans. 5. Awareness raising campaign implemented in all project districts.

1. SRS for database reengineering completed. 80% work completed with regards to the reengineering of CCIS, DIRS and development of the NCOC Software. 2.Small arms control action plan endorsed by MoHA. Prototypes for stockpile management being tested in Kailali. 3. MoHA has one fully equipped and functional coordination secretariat./ the bilateral security coordination support could not materialize owing to the shifting priorities in the aftermath of the earthquake and the blockade. 4.Six VDC cluster level CS plans implemented and 12 cluster level CS plans developed. Approx. USD 40,000 mobilized from local development budget for the implementation of the CS plans in 8 VDC and 2 municipalities. 5. A total of 68,253 population reached in 7 municipalities, 50 VDCs reached through Street drama, Video van, painting competition, speech competition, hoarding board, human bill board, door to door campaigns, football competition, interaction against dowry, witchcraft, Youth Police Activities.

1 NP database reengineering completed and NCOC software quality tested and operationalized, NCOC training curriculum finalized 2 Policy framework for operationalizing the NCOC drafted in coordination with the relevant stakeholders. 3 Community security plans developed and implemented in 18 VDC clusters across the seven project districts. 4 GBV prevention peer education manual roll out through the men engage alliance and other relevant partners. At least 100 peer educators trained.

description.narrative: Renewable Energy for Rural Livelihood (RERL) project focuses on off-grid renewable energy technologies to promote income generating opportunities and a low-carbon development path in rural areas of Nepal.
Output 2.4.1 Alternative Energy Promotion Center's (AEPC) capacity enhanced for scaling up energy services in the rural areas.

a) Total installed capacity of renewable energy-based power generation projects implemented by end-of-project (EOP) in MW
b) Electricity generated annually for livelihood and quality of life improvement (GWh/yr) by the EOP.

comment.narrative: a) Draft RE Policy Document Prepared b) 3,000 additional households connected to energy services c) Undertake 100 Micro-Hydro Rapid Assessment destroyed by April Earthquake d) Install 10 solar energy solutions to public institutions destroyed by April Earthquake

a) RE policy finalization is in the process. A stakeholder (DPs, line ministries, private sector etc.) consultation for RE policy has been conducted. Based on the feedback, GON/AEPC has prioritized to revise subsidy policy and delivery mechanism prior to the RE policy, as it was deemed important and relevant. RERL provided assistance to AEPC to draft Renewable Energy Subsidy Policy 2015. The final draft has been prepared and submitted to the line Ministry after consultations with AEPC, Development Partners (DPs), concerned government agencies and private sector. The new draft policy encourages private participation and PPP model in the RE sector. It also goes beyond the current practice of providing subsidy for equipment and includes provision for subsidizing services. The finalization of RE policy has now been pushed to next year. b) AEPC supported 3,581 households to connect to electricity with the support of RERL and NRREP (1,776 households directly connected by RERL and 1,805 households connected by NRREP with technical support from RERL). c) 100 MH Rapid Assessment completed and 40 additional rapid assessment ongoing. d) Installed 33 solar energy solutions to public institutions by RERL destroyed by April Earthquake and technically supported AEPC to install additional 9 solar energy solutions to public institutions.

comment.narrative: Not there
1. First Draft of SE4ALL National Action Agenda prepared 2.SE4ALL Country Action Agenda finalized in consultation with Government of Nepal and Donor Partners

First draft of SE4ALL National Action Agenda is prepared and is circulated for feedback with Government agencies, development partners, private sector and civil society who are part of SE4ALL coordination mechanism. In December the draft document is being consulted individually and in a wider forum with the relevant stakeholders towards finalization.

title.narrative: Local Governance and Community Development Programme

description.narrative: The Local Governance and Community Development Programme II : Policy and Programme Support Facility

title.narrative: LGCDPII_General Revision 3 dtd 17 Feb2015 with AWP
LGCDP_II_General Revision 1 Dtd Jan2014 with AWP
Signed Decision NAC Aide Memoire 31 July 2014
Local Governance and Community Development Programme
Local Governance and Community Development Programme

description.narrative: The Local Governance and Community Development Programme II : Policy and Programme Support Facility

activity-description.narrative: Mobilize local government and community development towards sector wide approach for decentralization.

description.narrative: Outcome 1 :Timely preparation of ASIP in line with LGCDP-II programme development objectives and targets; Implementation of ASIP; National Accountability Initiatives are closely aligned. Outcome 2 : Analytical work and field testing of reforms and innovations inform policy processes and decisions; All National level TA for LGCDP II implementation is fully managed by MoFALD; Improved aggregate local body performance in financial management, HR management, vital registration, M&E and overall reporting. Outcome 3: Better alignment between JFA and non JFA stakeholders; unified funding mechanisms for quality assurance and monitoring.

comment.narrative: Outcome 1. PCU in place; CCU in place; District and Municipal facilitators in place Outcome 2. Uncoordinated CD support; Uncoordinated TA support Outcome 3. Policy advice and coordination function procured directly by DPs outside LGCDP-1; programme assurance and reviews procured directly by DPs outside LGCDP-1

1. Provide technical assistance to the Ministry of Federal Affairs and Local Development ( MoFALD) and local bodies in strengthen timely programmatic and financial reporting 2. Support to initiate the process in establishment of Programme Recruitment Facility within MoFALD to capacitate the Government in managing technical assistance 3. Support the Ministry to stock take the achievements and lessons learned in implementation of livelihood implementation plan being implemented through the Local Governance and Community Development Program.

1. 80% of the local bodies submitted the financial reporting on time.The local bodies own source revenue, including revenue sharing, reached Rs 8.6 billion this fiscal year compared to Rs 7.29 billion in the last fiscal year, indicating the improvement in functions, financing and capacity of sub-national level institutions. This can be partly attributed to the TA provided by UNDP to help stronger planning, implementation and monitoring at the local level. Additionally, 46.24% of the priorities voiced through the participatory planning sessions at the ward level were included in the local development plans. 2. The draft framework guideline on Programme Recruitment Facility (PRF) was developed. The PRF task force has been constituted to pave the way for PRF functionality next year. 3. In October 2015, the LIP stocktaking exercise was cancelled as it was decided that the Mid Term review of LGCDP - planned for early 2016 would conduct the study.

1. Specialized technical service provided to MOFALD to prepare the restructuring plan of local bodies in terms of number and size of the village and urban municipalities. 2. Existing Acts/regulations related to local governance are revised as per the Federal context. 3.DDCs and municipalities provided technical support, guidance and mentoring in the hiring process of new program staff locally 4.Complete training needs assessment of the staff of the local bodies and develop training packages 5.Provide additional catalytic technical assistance in the field of decentralization, public finance management, Internal Revenue/ Taxation and Federalization.

description.narrative: Management Support to Country Programme Implementation (MaSCOPI). Outcome 2-9 as reflected in the UNDAF/CPAP

activity-description.narrative: Support effective and efficient management and implementation of CPAP (2013-2017)

title.narrative: Support to knowledge and lifelong learning skills-SKILLs

description.narrative: Output 1.1: national and sub-national systems and institutions enabled to achieve structural transformation of productive capacities that are sustainable and employment- and livelihoods-intensive.
The planned outcomes on completion are (a) 2012 Technical Vocational Education and Training (TVET) policy implemented; and (b) TVET provision is monitored and evaluated.

activity-description.narrative: The support will be provided for Ministry of Education and Council for Technical Education and Vocational Training (CTEVT).

description.narrative:
I) Inclusive TVET policy revised and prepared with participation of various stakeholders (the Ministry of Education, other ministries, private sector, donors, and training providers) in place, approved and implementation started.
II) (a) national system in place for the coordinated planning and assessment of TVET provisions; (b) basis for dealing with excess demand and requalification determined; (c) TVET publications

comment.narrative:
I) There is consensus on the quality of 2012 TVET policy, but also widespread recognition in government and amongst the development partners that there has been limited progress in its implementation.
II) Fragmentation of TVET provision (with many ministries and other public organisation providing TVET) and absence of any overarching M&E system in the subsector.

Activity Result 1: Policy dialogue established and instituted on a regular basis with stakeholders. Activity Result 2: Proposals for how to engage the private sector (businesses, industry and training providers) in TVET policy development, planning and implementation. Activity Result 3: TVET actions assessment system in place Activity result 4: TVET Publication of national and international significance Activity result 5: Establishment of labor market signaling system Activity Result 6: Programme Monitoring and Knowledge management

- Experts are hired to explore areas to establish a practical policy dialogue with the stakeholders - To engage private sector in TVET policy development and implementation, a high level national expert has been hired and assigned to review the system and engage the private sector in more effective ways. - For TVET action assessment, preliminary assessment of the ministry and the Council for Technical Education and Vocational Training (CTEVT) has been done. - Labor market signaling and Knowledge Management and Knowledge Networking System in TVET Sub-sector of Nepal, the project has initiated this works in partnership with the CTEVT. The CTEVT has accomplished the first phase of works and submitted reports.

participating-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

description.narrative: Supporting holistic and victim centered transitional justice process in Nepal.

participating-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

activity-description.narrative: Support the development of transitional justice mechanisms that is aligned with international standards and will strengthen the criminal justice system.

description.narrative: Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

provider-org.narrative: UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT
UNDP AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT FOR A JOINT PROGRAMME PASS THROUGH ARRANGEMENT

description.narrative:
"% of registered cases that are investigated by Transitional justice mechanisms in line with international standards (UNDAF 1 #8.1.2) Alternative Indicator: # of victims of gross human rights violations during the conflict who receive compensation (UNDAF 8.1.3)" # of victims of gross human rights violations during the conflict who receive comprehensive reparative benefits and services (UNDAF 1 #8.1.3) Action plan for the TJ mechanism developed and implemented # of women victims trained on women's engagement in the truth telling process
The Truth and Reconciliation Commission and Commission for the Investigation of Disappeared Persons have been established in February 2015 but yet to be fully functional.

comment.narrative: Neither Truth and Reconciliation Commission nor Commission of Inquiry on Disappearances established as of July 2012. Draft reparations policy and proposed reparations programme submitted to government 80 women leaders oriented on TJ and truth telling process
40% of the conflict affected persons receiving compensation increased by 50% Plan of action developed for the TJ mechanisms 4000 women victims trained on truth telling process and NAP 1325

Due to the earthquake that struck in Nepal in April and May 2015, and due to the complications relating to the laws establishing the TJ mechanisms, the project faced technical and other difficulties to deliver full-fledged activities, and consequently things slowed up. The project, however, did continue to engage with the Conflict Victims Common Platform (CVCP) in supporting their network strengthening and in supporting them to develop a coordinated approach through various regional meetings across the country so as to prepare them to better and efficiently engage with the TJ mechanisms, in the event they so wished (The CVCP has adopted a policy of critical engagement with the TJ mechanisms.). As a result of this, the Project was able to support five regional coordination meetings in March 2015 and an additional six regional meetings in December 2015. The Project also supported eight CVCP members for a weeks study tour in Bosnia and Herzegovina in September 2015 from where they derived lessons on victims initiatives on alternative truth telling, reconciliation and memorialization undertaken there. The Project also hosted a debriefing meeting of the Bosnia trip to the rest of the CVCP members in November in Kathmandu. Likewise, the Project also supported a retreat and planning meeting of the CVCP on 25-28 December in Pokhara, where 24 CVCP members were imparted a days team-building sessions; followed then by the CVCPs annual work plan development discussions the next day.

description.narrative: Building Back Better for Inclusive and Resilient Recovery in Nepal after Earthquake 2015

title.narrative: Approved emergency ASL letter Nepal CO US160000 to support Emergency Response to the Earthquake_27 April 2015
Building Back Better for Inclusive and Resilient Recovery in Nepal after Earthquake 2015

activity-description.narrative: Providing support for a comprehensive recovery after the earthquake in Nepal.
